awd_titl_txt: RCN-UBE Incubator:  Preparing a Network to Develop Molecular Case Studies at the Interface of Biology and Chemistry
awd_abstract_narration:
Understanding structure-function relationships is foundational to learning biology. In lower-division courses, students study the shapes and functions of selected proteins and nucleic acids. However, deep understanding of structure-function relationships requires visualizing the structure, mapping information from various biological data resources (e.g., polymer sequence, interactions, mutations, variations) onto the structure, and applying biology and/or chemistry knowledge to synthesize explanations of function. Unfortunately, these activities are not common in undergraduate biology curricula. Collaboration between biology, chemistry, and biochemistry educators to adapt molecular visualization approaches currently being used in chemistry can benefit biology education. To that end, the aim of this project is to establish a network of interested faculty that will create case studies, an effective active-learning technique, to teach the relationship between molecular structure and function. The cases will enable students to visualize and analyze challenging real-world problems in atomic detail and apply their biology and/or chemistry knowledge to develop solutions. These molecular visualizations will provide a platform for integrating knowledge from different sub-disciplines of biology, such as biochemistry, genetics, and cell biology to form the foundation for practicing interdisciplinary, team science across STEM disciplines.

This RCN-UBE project will establish a new network, Molecular CaseNet, to develop case studies at the interface of biology and chemistry. Objectives of the incubator phase of this project are to 1) bring together an interdisciplinary team of seven scientists and researchers to develop an exemplar for case-study design and determine format requirements for future case studies; 2) create two model case studies focused on specific biological processes/events and discussed at a molecular level; and 3) present the cases in community workshops and professional society meetings to recruit new members to the network and gather feedback on usability, clarity, and relevance of the case studies. Piloting the newly developed case studies with selected student groups will shed light on the relevance of these case studies in learning biology, chemistry, and biochemistry. By using the planned case studies, students with varied levels of expertise and disciplinary training will have the opportunity to understand molecular structure-function relationships and practice the scientific process to address real-world problems. In turn, this practice will help prepare the next generation of workers in STEM fields to creatively apply interdisciplinary approaches to problem-solving.

This project is being jointly funded by the Directorate for Biological Sciences, Division of Biological Infrastructure, and the Directorate for Education and Human Resources, Division of Undergraduate Education as part of their efforts to address the challenges posed in Vision and Change in Undergraduate Biology Education: A Call to Action (http://visionandchange/finalreport/).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Understanding the relationship between structure and function is foundational to learning biology. Students must learn and practice many steps to explore structure-function relationships in atomic detail. For example, identifying the three-dimensional (3D) structures of molecules related to the topic of study, visualizing them, mapping information from various biological data resources (e.g., polymer sequence, interactions, mutations, variations) onto the structure(s), and applying biology and chemistry knowledge to explain the functions. Undergraduate educators have access to limited active learning resources for teaching structure-function explorations in biology, chemistry, and biochemistry courses. Availability of more freely available, community-tested active-learning resources (such as case studies) would help many undergraduate educators enhance their curricula. This RCN-UBE Incubator project focused on establishing a network of educators and scholars to develop, pilot, and publish molecular case studies at the interface of biology and chemistry.

Seven researchers and educators collaborated to create Molecular CaseNet, a community of multidisciplinary educators, researchers, and scholars interested in developing and using molecular case studies. Discussions within the group helped establish the molecular case study cycle - a framework for creating and using these case studies. The group then collaboratively developed the first few examples of molecular case studies. Group members presented these example case studies in various workshops and professional society meetings to recruit educators for semester-long Faculty Mentoring Networks (FMNs). The FMNs focused on writing new molecular case studies and piloting available cases for usability, clarity, and relevance. Feedback from FMN participants helped improve the case studies and prepare them for publication online.

Some FMN participants challenged their students to author molecular case studies as a course-based undergraduate research experience (CURE). Instructions developed for the CURE jump-started the creation of detailed guidelines of a pipeline for authoring, piloting, and reviewing molecular case studies. The FMN participants also identified the need for additional educational resources to support students and educators in the structure-function explorations. Several of these have been developed and are now available as resources from the Molecular CaseNet website.  

In summary, this RCN-UBE Incubator project focused on addressing the need for open access, active learning resources for exploring biomolecular structure-function relationships. Molecular Casenet members have developed and published eight molecular case studies. Selected members of Molecular CaseNet have helped create a pipeline for collaboratively or independently authoring, piloting, reviewing, and publishing molecular case studies and supporting learning materials as open-access resources. Currently funded by an NSF RCN-UBE, Molecular CaseNet continues to engage educators in developing and using molecular case studies on multidisciplinary topics.
